articles.headline: U.S. Sues TikTok Over Child Privacy Violations
articles.snippet: The Justice Department said TikTok illegally collected children’s data and knowingly allowed users under the age of 13 to create accounts.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department said TikTok illegally collected children’s data and knowingly allowed users under the age of 13 to create accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department sued TikTok on Friday, accusing it of illegally collecting children’s data and escalating a long-running battle between the U.S. government and the Chinese-owned app.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Not One of Us: Trump Uses Old Tactic to Sow Suspicion About Harris
articles.snippet: Politicians have long cast their opponents as outsiders. But Donald J. Trump has taken the strategy to the next level against Kamala Harris.
articles.abstract: Politicians have long cast their opponents as outsiders. But Donald J. Trump has taken the strategy to the next level against Kamala Harris.
articles.lead_paragraph: She is not one of us.

articles.headline: Tech Bosses Preach Patience as They Spend and Spend on A.I.
articles.snippet: Big technology companies show no signs of slowing their spending on artificial intelligence, even though a payoff still looks a long way away.
articles.abstract: Big technology companies show no signs of slowing their spending on artificial intelligence, even though a payoff still looks a long way away.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, started 2023 by declaring it the “year of efficiency.” Like several of its big tech peers, Meta cut jobs and mothballed expansion plans.

articles.headline: So, Human Resources Is Making You Miserable?
articles.snippet: Get in line behind the H.R. managers themselves, who say that since the pandemic, the job has become an exasperating ordeal. “People hate us,” one said.
articles.abstract: Get in line behind the H.R. managers themselves, who say that since the pandemic, the job has become an exasperating ordeal. “People hate us,” one said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Show of hands: Who’s fed up with human resources?

articles.headline: Will A.I. Kill Meaningless Jobs?
articles.snippet: And is that so bad?
articles.abstract: And is that so bad?
articles.lead_paragraph: When Brad Wang started his first job in the tech industry, right after college, he marveled at the way Silicon Valley had turned the drudgery of the workplace into a sumptuousness of game rooms, nap pods and leafy hiking trails. This is what it must have felt like to be a guest showing up for a party at Jay Gatsby’s house, Mr. Wang thought.

articles.headline: In Gaza, Even Poetry and Toilets Aren’t Safe From Thieves
articles.snippet: Israel’s assault has driven Hamas underground, but for nearly two million Gazans, what followed in its wake is a lawlessness that is undermining communal trust.
articles.abstract: Israel’s assault has driven Hamas underground, but for nearly two million Gazans, what followed in its wake is a lawlessness that is undermining communal trust.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.
articles.byline: By Bilal Shbair and Erika Solomon

articles.headline: How JD Vance Thinks About Power
articles.snippet: Mr. Vance has been blunt about wanting to break norms and test constitutional limits to execute his ideas: “We have to get pretty wild, pretty far out there.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Vance has been blunt about wanting to break norms and test constitutional limits to execute his ideas: “We have to get pretty wild, pretty far out there.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In September 2021, JD Vance offered two predictions about former President Donald J. Trump and one piece of advice.

articles.headline: With Smugglers and Front Companies, China Is Skirting American A.I. Bans
articles.snippet: The U.S. is trying to stop China from getting Nvidia microchips to advance its military. The private sector is fighting back.
articles.abstract: The U.S. is trying to stop China from getting Nvidia microchips to advance its military. The private sector is fighting back.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen, a mazelike market stretches for a half-mile, packed with stalls selling every type of electronic imaginable.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Claire Fu

articles.headline: War Shatters Dating Scene for Women in Ukraine
articles.snippet: While the pursuit of love might seem secondary to dealing with the horrors and privations of the war, many Ukrainians say they need romantic relationships to help them cope.
articles.abstract: While the pursuit of love might seem secondary to dealing with the horrors and privations of the war, many Ukrainians say they need romantic relationships to help them cope.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past two and a half years, Kateryna Bairachna has wanted to meet someone special. But war always gets in the way.
articles.byline: By Constant Méheut, Daria Mitiuk and Oksana Parafeniuk

articles.headline: The Olympic Flame Melts Parisian Cool
articles.snippet: There are people walking around the world’s fashion capital with fluffy cockerels on their heads. This is not normal.
articles.abstract: There are people walking around the world’s fashion capital with fluffy cockerels on their heads. This is not normal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Félix Lebrun has the crowd eating out of the palm of his hand. He raises his arms. They cheer. He pumps his fists. They roar. He struts around the sold-out arena, prowling the floor, basking in the noise and the adulation.
articles.byline: By Rory Smith and Ségolène Le Stradic

articles.headline: Hamas May Emerge Battered, but Not Beaten, From Israel’s Latest Blows
articles.snippet: The assassinations of two Hamas leaders may be a short-term setback, analysts say, not enough to prevent the group from re-emerging intact — and possibly more radicalized.
articles.abstract: The assassinations of two Hamas leaders may be a short-term setback, analysts say, not enough to prevent the group from re-emerging intact — and possibly more radicalized.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

articles.headline: Has the Long Friendship of Bill Gates and Warren Buffett Reached Its Final Act?
articles.snippet: Growing tensions between the two billionaires, over issues both substantive and stylistic, have roiled the world of philanthropy.
articles.abstract: Growing tensions between the two billionaires, over issues both substantive and stylistic, have roiled the world of philanthropy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1991, Mary Gates, the mother of the Microsoft billionaire Bill Gates, convinced her workaholic 35-year-old son to spend the July 4 holiday at Hood Canal, a scenic, outdoorsy location about two hours from Seattle that had long been the family getaway.

articles.headline: A Battle Over a Farm, a Mosque and the Moral High Ground
articles.snippet: A proposed “Muslim-friendly” community near Minneapolis was called segregationist. The backlash was called Islamophobic. Who gets to define inclusion?
articles.abstract: A proposed “Muslim-friendly” community near Minneapolis was called segregationist. The backlash was called Islamophobic. Who gets to define inclusion?
articles.lead_paragraph: Butch Robinson is done. After dedicating most of his 77 years to growing sod, he just wants to sell his sprawl of green and ease his aching back into the lounge chair of a hard-earned retirement.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry and Jenn Ackerman

articles.headline: At Least 70 Dead as Bangladesh Protests Grow; Curfew Is Reinstated
articles.snippet: Expanded student protests this weekend, after more than 200 people were killed in a government crackdown in July, have plunged the country into a particularly dangerous phase.
articles.abstract: Expanded student protests this weekend, after more than 200 people were killed in a government crackdown in July, have plunged the country into a particularly dangerous phase.
articles.lead_paragraph: At least 70 people were killed in clashes between security forces and protesters on Sunday in Bangladesh, as the country’s leaders imposed a new curfew and internet restrictions to try to quell a growing antigovernment movement.
articles.byline: By Saif Hasnat and Mujib Mashal

articles.headline: How Two Russian Spies Went Deep Undercover With Their Children
articles.snippet: A couple planted as sleeper spies in Slovenia posed as an Argentine art dealer and an entrepreneur. They were caught in December 2022 and sent to Moscow in a sweeping prisoner exchange last week.
articles.abstract: A couple planted as sleeper spies in Slovenia posed as an Argentine art dealer and an entrepreneur. They were caught in December 2022 and sent to Moscow in a sweeping prisoner exchange last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Darja Stefancic, a painter in Slovenia known for technicolor landscapes, thought it strange when an obscure online art gallery run by a woman from Argentina contacted her out of the blue and asked her to join its thin roster of artists.

articles.headline: Declaring ‘Crisis,’ South Korean Firms Tell Managers to Work 6 Days a Week
articles.snippet: The move by some influential companies has raised concerns about work-life balance in a country where long hours at the office are common.
articles.abstract: The move by some influential companies has raised concerns about work-life balance in a country where long hours at the office are common.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Back in the day,” said Lim Hyung-kyu, a retired Samsung Electronics executive now in his 70s, “my weeks were Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Friday, Friday.”

articles.headline: Fears of Slowing U.S. Growth Jolt Markets Around the World
articles.snippet: A rout that began in Asia continued in Europe, and U.S. stocks fell sharply. Some investors said the sell-off was an overdue pullback.
articles.abstract: A rout that began in Asia continued in Europe, and U.S. stocks fell sharply. Some investors said the sell-off was an overdue pullback.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anxiety over a slowdown in the U.S. economy intensified on Monday, with a retreat in markets that began last week snowballing into a global rout.The turmoil was the latest example of how distinct economic forces can ricochet across markets, forcing down company stock prices and erasing billions of dollars in value. In this case, a rapidly rising yen over the past week had disrupted the flow of global capital, prompting a pullback from some popular investments.But the sell-off quickly expanded into a more widespread panic that the Federal Reserve may have waited too long to start cutting interest rates, threatening the strength of the U.S. economy.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison, Daisuke Wakabayashi and River Akira Davis

articles.headline: How 2024 Became the Zoom Election
articles.snippet: Hastily assembled mega-rallies conducted over Zoom are raising millions to elect Kamala Harris, giving the videoconferencing app an unexpected role in this year’s campaign.
articles.abstract: Hastily assembled mega-rallies conducted over Zoom are raising millions to elect Kamala Harris, giving the videoconferencing app an unexpected role in this year’s campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: A month ago, if you had asked me which tech platforms would play a major role in the 2024 presidential campaign, I might have said TikTok or Facebook. I might have said YouTube. I may have even theorized that X would still play a role despite its hard-right turn under Elon Musk’s ownership.

articles.headline: A Year After a Devastating Fire, Lahaina Is Ready to Rebuild. But How?
articles.snippet: Much of the fire-ravaged community on the island of Maui has been cleared of debris. But for a town steeped in history, there are thorny questions about what the future should look like.
articles.abstract: Much of the fire-ravaged community on the island of Maui has been cleared of debris. But for a town steeped in history, there are thorny questions about what the future should look like.
articles.lead_paragraph: Across nine generations, Archie Kalepa’s family has seen the waterfront in Lahaina, a town on the island of Maui, undergo repeated transformation.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker, Tim Arango and Philip Cheung

articles.headline: Traders Bet on Fed Emergency Rate Cuts, but Officials Need More to React
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve cuts rates outside of scheduled meetings only in extreme cases. But job market weakening could make for bigger rate cuts down the road.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve cuts rates outside of scheduled meetings only in extreme cases. But job market weakening could make for bigger rate cuts down the road.
articles.lead_paragraph: As turmoil swept through global financial markets on Monday, fueled by concerns that the economy is headed for a hard landing, investors began to speculate that the Federal Reserve could jump in to cushion the fallout with an emergency interest rate cut.

articles.headline: Advice: When the Stock Market Drops, Stay Calm and Do Nothing
articles.snippet: There is no reason to think that you can predict what will happen in the markets in the next few hours or in the near future. It’s better not to try.
articles.abstract: There is no reason to think that you can predict what will happen in the markets in the next few hours or in the near future. It’s better not to try.
articles.lead_paragraph: Think of what’s happening in the stock market as a kind of fire drill. As we all know from childhood, one of the primary rules is not to panic. And in this case, panicking would mean selling stocks when the market is falling.

articles.headline: To Become the GOAT, Simone Biles First Had to Be a Turtle
articles.snippet: She sealed her legacy with four medals at the Paris Games. She created it by being herself and going at her own pace.
articles.abstract: She sealed her legacy with four medals at the Paris Games. She created it by being herself and going at her own pace.
articles.lead_paragraph: To end the Olympics she once thought would never happen for her, Simone Biles began her floor exercise routine on Monday and did what she was made to do: flip and twist and thrill an arena filled with people there to watch her.
